justification: The article presents the DPOWER model as a novel computational approach to capture the complex relationship between effort and value. It specifically aids in modeling individual differences in effort-value relationships by integrating the contributions of both positive and negative evaluation subsystems, demonstrating its superior explanatory power compared to other models.

The paper employs a logit model fitted to participants' choices to determine the effect of temporal orientation (prospective or retrospective) on effort-value relationships. Results highlight distinct patterns, such as the greater likelihood of choosing effortful options in the retrospective condition compared to the prospective condition.

topic_or_construct: Hypothetical vs. real task impact on effort-value
justification: Analysis of choice data shows the interaction between effort intensity and task type (hypothetical vs. real). In the prospective condition, effort had a more pronounced negative impact in hypothetical tasks, while the opposite occurred in the retrospective condition, suggesting task type influences effort-value relations.

measured_by: Parametric Estimation by Sequential Testing (PEST) procedure and DPOWER model
justification: The PEST procedure was used to elicit various individual effort-value relationships. The DPOWER model then identified four distinct preference profiles—decreasing, increasing, decreasing-increasing, and increasing-decreasing—providing insight into individual differences in effort evaluation.
